intro: Acacia telmica, commonly known as the white wattle, is a shrub or small tree native to arid and semi-arid regions of Australia. It is characterized by its slender, often multi-branched stems and feathery, bipinnate leaves. The plant produces small, yellow flowers arranged in cylindrical spikes, which are typical of the Acacia genus. Acacia telmica is adapted to withstand drought and high temperatures, making it well-suited to harsh environments. Its seeds are encased in pods and can remain viable in the soil for extended periods.

Its species is Acacia telmica, a specific type of acacia found in certain regions, known for its ecological and potential medicinal significance.

It is found in the southern and central regions of the state, particularly in the areas of the Geraldton and Shark Bay regions. This plant thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in sandy soils. It is commonly found in coastal dunes and inland shrublands. Acacia telmica plays an important ecological role in stabilizing soils and providing habitat for local wildlife.
